DOC.HEAD: Water Losses Caused by Cold Plague Residents
With AM-Cold Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Like thousands of Houstonians, Linda Woods spent the Christmas holidays bedeviled by problems caused by the record cold. On Saturday morning, the pipes in her attic froze. ``No coffee, no shower, nothing,'' she said. The single mother packed up her two children and went to her mother's home, which had water. After an hour, the electricity went out as utilities were overloaded by the demand for heat. Two hours later, the family went shopping to keep warm at a mall. ``We were there about an hour and all their lights went off,'' Ms. Woods said. When they returned to her mother's home, the water was off because a pump station lost power. The family went to a hotel Sunday morning, with the kids amusing themselves ``by feeding about $20 in quarters into the Magic Fingers thing on the motel bed while Mom and I played cards.'' When the family returned to Ms. Woods' mother's house on Christmas Day, there was electricity but no water. On Tuesday, Ms. Woods and her children went home to find her pipes thawed _ and her kitchen and living room flooded because the ice had ruptured the pipes. ``The phone still worked, so I called my mom and said, `Mom, come on over _ I've got water,'' she joked. Paul Harrison, a 24-year-old University of Houston student, had been excited when his parents from the Texas Panhandle decided to visit for the holidays for the first time. But then the electricity went off Saturday and the water dwindled to a rusty trickle. ``The really bad part was, I've called them every week since I've been here and gloated over the weather,'' Harrison said. ``I really wish I hadn't done that.''
